data.text: Maxxis Rambler vs Maxxis Ravager

Hello all, Tires. It‚Äôs time for some new gravel tires and I have a hard time choosing between these two - maxxis rambler vs ravager. Looking for something with less rolling resistance (rambler) but with better grip (ravager). And will also be riding on pavement. I‚Äôm leaning more towards the rambler.. OR ravager front with rambler rear? ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Q: does any one have any experience with any of these tires, all input/comments are welcome.
to be honest, neither. maxxis needs to update the gravel line IMO.
data.author: Dustin Bise

data.text: Consider Rambler on rear & Ravanger on front. Efficiency where there‚Äôs more weight, and extra grip up front to reduce washout risk. Not familiar w/ those tires, but have been happy w/ Conti Terra Speed rear & Terra Trail front. Same idea. Set pressure per ride requirements since you‚Äôre mixing surfaces. I go 38/40 if mostly paved, 34/36 if mostly gravel, and 30/32 if loose and steep.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: Wow I was actually thinking of that last night - ravager front and rambler rear. And noted for the pressures, I do set pressure every single time before a ride. Thx for you reply!
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: Even if I'm just over 200lbs on 40s for those pressures? Thx
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text:
your pressure would be a little higher. Reco using the Zipp calculator. That will get you the pavement and general gravel pressures. Take a few pounds off the gravel ones to get the loose/steep setting. https://axs.sram.com/guides/tire/pressure
SRAM | AXS
axs.sram.com
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: I second the above
data.author: Craig Dodrill

data.text: Rambler rear, Ravanger front
data.author: Craig Dodrill

data.text: That makes completely sense to me with my mtb background üëçüëç
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I like the ramblers for where I live. Most of the gravel here is loose over hardpack or sandy. The ramblers handle it pretty well. If you need more grip, then I‚Äôd go with putting the aggressive tire up front.
data.author: Tyler Stabile

data.text: Thanks for sharing, I think I'll do that üëç
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I‚Äôve been running the Rambler front and rear in a 700x45 and love them. For the main gravel ride I do, it‚Äôs 20miles of pavement before I hit the gravel. They‚Äôre great and you‚Äôd be surprised how well they track in gravel with the small knobby pattern. I ran this tire in the Rebecca‚Äôs Private Idaho gravel race last year with no issues. I already have a second set ready to go.
data.author: Bryan Powell

data.text: Yes, my rides are a mix of all terrain, pavement, gravel and light single tracks so rolling well is also something I have to consider. Thanks for your reply!
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: One of my main riding partners purchased these and also loves them. I‚Äôm riding them tomorrow on this same route: pavement, gravel, and single-track and the end. About 50miles. They‚Äôre also reasonably priced, so not a huge outlay. What size are you considering? My daughter runs these in a 700x40 and they‚Äôre also performing well.
data.author: Bryan Powell

data.text: I run 700X45 Ramblers for that same mix of surfaces (some pavement, lots of gravel and some single track) on the Front Range of Colorado and have liked them so far and have had zero issues. I concur Bryan Powell.
data.author: Mike Archer

data.text: I‚Äôm thinking 700x45 front and 40 rear. Currently running the 700x40 F&R Refuse
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I‚Äôve never run a mix of sizes, not sure if it ultimately affects the tracking/handling. It does complicate things if you want to swap tires, or stock up on tire purchases. If you have clearance for the 700x45‚Äôs in the rear, I would run all the same size.
data.author: Bryan Powell

data.text: Wider front Narrower rear idea/theory/logic comes from my mtb background üòÖ if not I‚Äôll keep all 40s since the Chainstay won‚Äôt clear 45 I think ü§î
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: gotcha. Good luck on your questüëç

data.text: thanks, appreciate ü§ôüèΩ

data.text: I second the tracking. Quite a bit of precision on chunky loose gravel.
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: Hmm.. Something to consider.. Thx üëç
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I have run 45 & 50 ramblers and they were a good tire here on Kansas gravel however I had some sidewall issues when pushing the tires into deep gravel situations and light MTB trail use. I have moved on to travail cannonballs durable version and even know they look like they would have less traction the cannonballs have felt more planted & rolled faster. Hope this helps
data.author: Cliff Jones

data.text: Thanks for sharing! Noted on the cannonballs üëç
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: you can have both! Mtb style - ravager in front, rambler in back. Traction in front, speed in the back.
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm thinking with my mtb background üëç
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: a lot of folks run this combo from the reviews I‚Äôve read. Something I have considered countless times.
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: I run this combo and it‚Äôs great!
data.author: Nicholas Snider

data.text: I think I've settled on ravager front and rambler rear! Thx guys!
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: after all the comments I think I'm going to get a set of the Ramblers too. Tanwall, 650 x 47. And he receptor doesn't look bad for the kind of riding I do - mix of road and off. Decisions....
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: I did a gravel race on Ramblers last year with a 700x40 rear and 700x50 front. The rambler is good on on anything except very loose, very steep, or very wet. I was flying down descents on 1‚Äù gravel roads and on dry wooded singletrack. Where they fell short for me was climbing loose grades more than 10*. Just not enough lug to grab loose leaves/sticks/dirt. They are fast on pavement. No flats in the race. I‚Äôm considering running them again in a 45 front and 40 rear if conditions aren‚Äôt wet. I did get one flat riding bike paths that orange seal endurance sealant wouldn‚Äôt close, but I think it was just freak hitting something.
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: Wow.. Good info, thanks for sharing! I was originally planning on ramblers 50 front and 45 rear but I don't think my fork will clear 50, so 45 front and 40 rear üòÖ
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: if you do, I‚Äôd suggest going for the 120 tpi version. 45 front 40 rear is a good combo. If it‚Äôs not enough grip you can always try a ravager front later, but ravager only comes in a 40 so it will mess with you geometry (handlebar placement, seat angle) a little bit swapping back and forth between sizes.
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: Oo really? Good to know, thx. I think I‚Äôll go with 40 ravager front and 40 rambler rear üßê
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: Look at Rene Herse tires.
data.author: Jim Evans

data.text: Noted, thx for sharing
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I run a 700/40 Ravager on front and 700/38 Rambler on the rear. I run a lot of single track so wanted a bit more hook up in the front and notice no difference on the road from the 40 Rambler front I used to run.
data.author: Mike Kavan

data.text: This is good to know, Thx!
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I'm been runner the setup you are thinking about, Revanger on the front and rambler on the rear for a few years now and been really happy with it. Able to ride about anything from county gravel, forest roads in the mountains, and some so gle track.
data.author: Robert Conatser

data.text: what about races with downhill starts?? üòÅ

data.text: Good stuff, thanks for sharing. I think I'll go with that setup - ravager front and rambler rear! üëç
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I am running my 3rd pair of Ramblers 45. The current pair however are not sitting properly even after several attempts with change of sealant. Not a serious gravel rider with 80% tarmac most of the time.
data.author: Said Mokti

data.text: Personally where I live (MN) these are pretty aggressive looking. I ride cannonballs. Almost 3k miles on one set, love them. They roll fast on pavement too
data.author: Reed Osell

data.text: noted, thanks for sharing.
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: Ramblers a great all around choice. A tried and true tire that‚Äôs stood the test of time and still an excellent choice.
data.author: Scott M. LeRette

data.text:
Maxxis doesn't seem to put near the emphasis in their gravel tires as they do their MTB tires. I would recommend looking at other brands. If you look at https://www.bicyclerollingresistance.com/CX-gravel-reviews Maxxis is near the bottom of the list as far as rolling resistance and doesn't do great with puncture resistance either.
CX/Gravel Bike Tires Test Results | Bicycle Rolling Resistance
bicyclerollingresistance.com
data.author: Philip Ross Jackson

data.text: I run ramblers (38s) and they are so fast and grippy on everything. I‚Äôm in Michigan so no steep climbs but plenty of single track and road.
data.author: Jack Donegan

data.text: Maxxis is my last choice for a gravel tire. I'm using the Unden br erican classic. Ive also ran the Terravail cannonballs too. Way better feeling tires.
data.author: Scott Elder

data.text: Conti Terra Speed. I used to run Ramblers.

data.text: If you want a pair of very lightly used 40mm Ramblers let me know by DM.
